cards.title: Moore's Law
cards.content: Why does your phone get faster every year? Thank Gordon Moore (co-founder of Intel). In 1965, he predicted that the number of transistors on a microchip would double every two years, while the cost would halve. This is Moore's Law. It explains why the smartphone in your pocket is millions of times more powerful than the computer that sent Apollo 11 to the moon. It’s an exponential curve. However, we are finally hitting the limits of physics—chips are getting so small that atoms are starting to interfere. The era of Moore's Law might be ending, but it built the modern world.
cards.keyTakeaway: Computing power tends to double every two years.

quiz.question: Moore's Law predicts that computing power will:
choices: B: Stay the same but get cheaper
quiz.explanation: It predicts a doubling of transistors (and thus power) approximately every two years.

cards.imagePrompt: A vintage 1960s computer filling a room next to a tiny modern smartphone. The smartphone is glowing with more power. A graph line shoots upward exponentially. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: The Cloud
cards.content: Where do your photos go when you upload them to 'The Cloud'? They don't float in the sky. They go to a massive, windowless warehouse in Virginia (or Oregon, or Ireland) filled with humming servers. 'The Cloud' is just a marketing term for 'Someone Else's Computer.' Companies like Amazon (AWS) and Google own these massive server farms. When you stream Netflix, you are pulling video files from a physical hard drive sitting on a rack in a building hundreds of miles away. It’s not magic; it’s infrastructure.
cards.keyTakeaway: 'The Cloud' is just a physical server farm owned by a company.

quiz.question: What is 'The Cloud' physically?
choices: B: Huge data centers filled with servers
quiz.explanation: It refers to remote servers hosted in data centers that store and process your data.

cards.imagePrompt: A fluffy white cloud in the sky. Inside the cloud, you can see rows of blinking black server racks and wires. Dark Blue #34495E tech aesthetic.

cards.title: CAPTCHAs
cards.content: You check a box: 'I am not a robot.' Then you select all the squares with traffic lights. Why? You aren't just proving you're human; you are working for free. You are training AI. CAPTCHAs (Completely Automated Public Turing test) use humans to identify things that computers struggle with. When you identify a stop sign, you are teaching a self-driving car algorithm what a stop sign looks like. When you type in a wavy word, you are helping digitize old books. You are a tiny, unpaid teacher for the machines.
cards.keyTakeaway: When you solve a CAPTCHA, you are training AI.

quiz.question: What is the secondary purpose of many CAPTCHA tests?
choices: A: To slow down the internet
B: To train AI to recognize images/text
quiz.explanation: Companies use the human input from CAPTCHAs to label data for machine learning models.

cards.imagePrompt: A robot student sitting at a desk. A human teacher is pointing at a picture of a traffic light. The robot is taking notes. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: The First 'Bug'
cards.content: Why do we call computer errors 'bugs'? Because the first one was literal. In 1947, computer pioneer Grace Hopper was working on the Mark II computer at Harvard. It malfunctioned. When they opened the massive machine, they found a moth stuck in a relay switch. It had been 'electrocuted' and stopped the circuit. They taped the dead moth into the logbook with the note: 'First actual case of bug being found.' We've been 'debugging' code ever since, though usually, the pests are logic errors, not insects.
cards.keyTakeaway: The first computer bug was a real moth trapped in a machine.

quiz.question: Who found the first literal computer bug?
quiz.explanation: Grace Hopper and her team found a moth inside the Mark II computer in 1947.

cards.imagePrompt: A vintage engineering logbook. Taped to the page is a real moth. A magnifying glass hovers over it. Text 'DEBUGGING'. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Bluetooth's Viking Origins
cards.content: Why is it called Bluetooth? And why is the logo that weird shape? It’s named after King Harald Bluetooth, a 10th-century Viking king who united the dissonant tribes of Denmark and Norway. The inventors of the tech (from Ericsson) wanted to 'unite' devices (phones and computers) just like the King united tribes. The logo is a combination of two Nordic Runes: ᚼ (H) and ᛒ (B) for Harald Bluetooth. It was supposed to be a temporary codename, but it stuck. Your headphones are paying tribute to a Viking.
cards.keyTakeaway: Bluetooth is named after a Viking king who united tribes.

quiz.question: The Bluetooth logo is a combination of:
quiz.explanation: It combines the runic initials H and B for King Harald Bluetooth.

cards.imagePrompt: A Viking King holding a smartphone. He has a glowing blue tooth. The Bluetooth logo floats in the air as a magical rune. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: QWERTY Keyboard
cards.content: Look at your keyboard. Why is 'Q' next to 'W'? It makes no sense. The QWERTY layout was designed in the 1870s for mechanical typewriters. If typists typed too fast, the metal arms would jam together. The layout was specifically designed to separate common letter pairs (like 'TH' or 'ST') to slow typists down slightly or prevent jams. We don't use mechanical arms anymore, but we are so used to QWERTY that we can't switch to more efficient layouts (like Dvorak). We are stuck with 19th-century anti-jamming tech.
cards.keyTakeaway: QWERTY was designed to prevent typewriter jams, not for speed.

quiz.question: Why are the keys arranged in QWERTY order?
choices: B: To prevent mechanical typewriters from jamming
quiz.explanation: It separated commonly used letter pairs to stop the mechanical arms from crashing into each other.

cards.imagePrompt: A mechanical typewriter with its keys all jammed and tangled. A modern keyboard is overlaid on top. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Internet vs WWW
cards.content: People use 'Internet' and 'Web' interchangeably. They are different. The Internet is the infrastructure—the massive network of cables, routers, and satellites connecting computers. It’s the roads. The World Wide Web (WWW) is just one service that runs *on top* of the internet. It’s the websites you visit via a browser. It’s the shops on the road. You can use the internet without the web (Email, Skype, Online Gaming). The Internet was born in the 60s; the Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989. You are on the Web right now, using the Internet.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Internet is the network; the Web is the pages you browse.

quiz.question: True or False: The Internet and the World Wide Web are the exact same thing.
quiz.explanation: False. The Internet is the infrastructure; the Web is a service (like email) that runs on that infrastructure.

cards.imagePrompt: A highway system (labeled 'Internet') with cars. On the side of the road are billboards and shops (labeled 'Web'). Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Digital Cookies
cards.content: Websites ask you to 'Accept Cookies.' They aren't snacks. A cookie is a tiny text file saved on your browser. It acts like a wristband at a club. It tells the website 'I've been here before.' Without cookies, you couldn't stay logged in—every time you clicked a new page, the site would forget who you are. 'First-party' cookies are helpful (saving your cart). 'Third-party' cookies are the creepy ones—advertisers use them to track you across *different* sites to show you ads for those shoes you looked at once.
cards.keyTakeaway: Cookies are text files that help websites remember you.

quiz.question: What is the main function of a web cookie?
choices: A: To give you a discount
B: To identify you and save your preferences
quiz.explanation: It stores small amounts of data so the website recognizes your device.

cards.imagePrompt: A computer monitor eating a chocolate chip cookie. The crumbs are binary code (1s and 0s). An 'Accept' button is glowing. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Algorithms Explained
cards.content: People talk about 'The Algorithm' like it's a god. In reality, an algorithm is just a fancy word for a recipe. It is a set of step-by-step instructions to solve a problem. A recipe for cake is an algorithm: Input (ingredients) -> Process (mix/bake) -> Output (cake). TikTok's algorithm is just: Input (you watched a cat video) -> Process (find similar videos) -> Output (show you more cats). They aren't magic; they are just logic rules written by humans to keep you clicking.
cards.keyTakeaway: An algorithm is just a set of instructions, like a recipe.

quiz.question: What is an algorithm fundamentally?
choices: B: A set of step-by-step instructions
quiz.explanation: It is simply a defined sequence of rules to perform a task or solve a problem.

cards.imagePrompt: A chef cooking. The cookbook is labeled 'Algorithm'. The ingredients are 'Data'. The final dish is 'Your Feed'. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: VPNs
cards.content: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) is like a secret tunnel for your data. Normally, when you visit a site, your data walks down the public street. Your ISP (Internet Service Provider) can see exactly where you are going. With a VPN, your data puts on a disguise and walks through a private tunnel. It pops out in a different country. The website thinks you are in Germany, even if you are in Ohio. It protects privacy on public WiFi and lets you watch Netflix shows that are blocked in your country.
cards.keyTakeaway: A VPN creates a private, encrypted tunnel for your internet traffic.

quiz.question: What is the main benefit of using a VPN on public WiFi?
choices: A: It makes the WiFi faster
B: It encrypts your data so hackers can't see it
quiz.explanation: It secures the connection, preventing others on the same network from snooping on your data.

cards.imagePrompt: A car (representing data) driving into a mountain tunnel. It enters as a red car and exits the other side as a blue car. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: 404 Not Found
cards.content: Why is the error code for a missing page always 404? There is a popular myth that the first web servers at CERN were in Room 404, and if you couldn't find a file, you had to go ask the guys in Room 404. It’s a great story, but it’s false. CERN didn't have a Room 404. The number is just logical: '4xx' codes represent Client Errors. '404' specifically means 'Not Found.' It was just the fourth error in the 'Client Error' category. Boring, but true. The room myth is just nerd folklore.
cards.keyTakeaway: 404 is just a standard error code, not a room number at CERN.

quiz.question: What does a 404 error signify?
choices: B: The page you requested cannot be found
quiz.explanation: It means the server is working, but the specific page you asked for doesn't exist.

cards.imagePrompt: A door with the number 404. The door is slightly open, revealing nothing but a void/space behind it. A 'Missing' poster hangs on it. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Encryption
cards.content: How do you send a secret message online without hackers reading it? You use Public Key Encryption. Imagine a box with an open padlock. You (the website) send the open box to me. I put my message (credit card number) in the box and lock it. Now, *only* you have the key to open it. Even if a hacker steals the box while it's being sent back to you, they can't open it. They don't have the key. This (HTTPS) is how the entire secure internet works. Without it, online banking would be impossible.
cards.keyTakeaway: Encryption works like a lockbox where only the receiver has the key.

quiz.question: In Public Key Encryption, who has the key to unlock the message?
quiz.explanation: The sender uses a public key to lock it, but only the receiver's private key can unlock it.

cards.imagePrompt: A digital treasure chest with a glowing padlock. Data is flying into it. A hacker with a crowbar is trying to open it but failing. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: IP Addresses
cards.content: Every device on the internet has an IP (Internet Protocol) address. It’s like your digital home address (e.g., 192.168.1.1). It tells data where to go. The problem? The old system (IPv4) only had 4.3 billion addresses. We ran out years ago because everyone has a phone, laptop, and smart fridge now. So we invented IPv6. IPv6 addresses are huge alphanumeric strings. It allows for 340 undecillion addresses. That is enough to give every single atom on the surface of the Earth its own IP address. We won't run out again.
cards.keyTakeaway: An IP address is your device's digital location on the internet.

quiz.question: Why did we switch from IPv4 to IPv6?
choices: B: We ran out of IPv4 addresses
quiz.explanation: The explosive growth of the internet exhausted the 4.3 billion available addresses in the old system.

cards.imagePrompt: A mailbox with a digital number on it. A drone is delivering a letter (data) to the mailbox. The house is made of circuit boards. Dark Blue #34495E.

cards.title: Bandwidth vs Latency
cards.content: Internet speed has two parts. Bandwidth is the *width* of the pipe (how much water can flow at once). Latency is the *speed* of the water (how fast a drop gets from A to B). If you have high Bandwidth but high Latency, you can download a huge movie fast, but your online game will lag. The movie buffers (fills the pipe), but the game needs instant reaction (speed). Satellite internet often has good bandwidth but terrible latency because the signal has to travel to space and back. For gaming, you want low latency (Ping).
cards.keyTakeaway: Bandwidth is volume; Latency is travel time.

quiz.question: Which is more important for real-time online gaming?
quiz.explanation: Gaming requires instant data transfer (low delay), whereas downloading files cares more about volume.

cards.title: Open Source
cards.content: Imagine if Coca-Cola published their secret recipe and said, 'Anyone can cook this, change it, and sell it.' That is Open Source software. Linux, Android, and Firefox are open source. Anyone can see the code. Why do this? Because thousands of volunteers fix bugs faster than one company can. Most of the internet runs on Linux. It’s a collaborative utopia where people build tools for the common good. Opposed to 'Closed Source' (like Windows or iOS), where the code is a locked trade secret. The web is built on sharing.
cards.keyTakeaway: Open Source means the software code is free for anyone to use and improve.

quiz.question: Which of these is an example of Open Source?
quiz.explanation: Linux code is publicly available for anyone to inspect, modify, and distribute.

cards.title: Phishing
cards.content: Hacking isn't usually typing furious code like in the movies. It’s usually just asking you for your password. This is Phishing. You get an email: 'Netflix: Payment Failed. Click here.' You click, see a fake Netflix login page, and type your password. The hacker records it. They didn't hack Netflix; they hacked *you*. It’s called 'Social Engineering.' The weakest link in any security system is always the human. Always check the sender's email address (e.g., if it says 'netflix-support@gmail.com', it’s a scam).
cards.keyTakeaway: Phishing tricks you into voluntarily giving up your password.

quiz.question: What is the most common way hackers get passwords?
quiz.explanation: It is much easier to trick a human into typing their password than to break encryption.

cards.title: Blockchain
cards.content: Forget crypto for a second. Imagine a Google Doc that everyone can read and write to, but *nobody* can delete or edit what is already written. That is a Blockchain. It’s a digital ledger shared across thousands of computers. To cheat, you'd have to hack 51% of those computers at the exact same time (impossible). This creates 'Trustless' systems—you don't need a bank to verify a transaction; the math verifies it. It’s a way to keep records that are permanent and un-hackable. Bitcoin is just the first app to use this tech.
cards.keyTakeaway: Blockchain is a shared digital record that cannot be altered.

quiz.question: What makes Blockchain secure?
choices: A: It is hidden in a vault
B: The data is distributed across many computers and cannot be edited
quiz.explanation: Decentralization prevents any single entity from altering the record.

cards.title: 5G Explained
cards.content: People are scared of 5G towers. What is it? It’s just radio waves, like 4G, but at a higher frequency. Higher frequency means it can carry way more data (speed!), but the waves are shorter, so they can't travel as far or penetrate walls well. That’s why 5G towers need to be everywhere—on every lamppost—because the signal is fragile. It’s not mind control; it’s just physics. It allows for things like remote surgery and self-driving cars that need instant data without lag. It’s faster, but shorter-range.
cards.keyTakeaway: 5G is faster than 4G but has a shorter range.

quiz.question: Why does 5G require more towers than 4G?
choices: A: The signal doesn't travel as far
quiz.explanation: Higher frequency waves have shorter wavelengths and get blocked easily by obstacles.

cards.title: RAM vs Hard Drive
cards.content: Computers have two types of memory. Think of your computer like a kitchen. The Hard Drive is the pantry: it stores all your ingredients (files) permanently. It’s huge but slow to access. RAM (Random Access Memory) is the countertop: it’s where you put the ingredients you are cooking with *right now*. It’s super fast but small. When you turn the computer off, the countertop (RAM) gets wiped clean. More RAM means a bigger countertop, so you can do more things at once without running back to the pantry.
cards.keyTakeaway: RAM is for active tasks; Hard Drive is for long-term storage.

quiz.question: When you turn off your computer, what happens to the data in RAM?
quiz.explanation: RAM is volatile memory; it needs power to hold data.

cards.title: The Dark Web
cards.content: The 'Dark Web' sounds like a villain's lair. In reality, it’s just the part of the internet not indexed by Google. You need a special browser (like Tor) to see it. Tor bounces your signal around the world to hide your identity. While it is used for crime (buying drugs, hire-a-hacker), it is also used by journalists, activists in dictatorships, and whistleblowers to communicate safely without government censorship. It’s not inherently evil; it’s just private. It’s the digital equivalent of a meeting in a basement with the lights off.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Dark Web is encrypted and hidden from search engines.

quiz.question: Can you access the Dark Web with a standard Chrome browser?
choices: B: No, you need special software
quiz.explanation: It requires specific software like Tor to access the encrypted networks.

cards.title: Pixels
cards.content: Look closely at your screen. Closer. You see millions of tiny colored dots? Those are pixels (Picture Elements). Each pixel is actually made of three tiny lights: Red, Green, and Blue (RGB). By mixing these three lights at different intensities, your screen can make 16 million colors. Yellow is just Red + Green lit up together. White is all three on full blast. Black is all three turned off. Your entire digital life—every movie, photo, and meme—is just a mosaic of three colors tricking your eye.
cards.keyTakeaway: Every color on your screen is a mix of Red, Green, and Blue.

quiz.question: How does a screen make the color yellow?
choices: A: By turning on a yellow light
B: By mixing Red and Green lights
quiz.explanation: Screens use additive color mixing (RGB). Red + Green light = Yellow light to the human eye.

cards.title: Trojan Horse
cards.content: A Trojan Horse is a type of malware named after the Greek myth. The Greeks couldn't enter Troy, so they hid inside a giant wooden horse gift. The Trojans brought it inside, and the Greeks attacked. In tech, a Trojan is a virus disguised as a useful program. You download a 'Free Screensaver' or 'Game Crack.' It works, but inside, it carries a hidden payload that steals your passwords or spies on you. Unlike a Virus, a Trojan doesn't replicate itself; it relies on *you* to invite it in. Don't accept gifts from strangers.
cards.keyTakeaway: Malware disguised as legitimate software.

quiz.question: Does a Trojan Horse virus replicate itself?
choices: B: No, it relies on the user to download it
quiz.explanation: Trojans must be installed by the user (usually by trickery), unlike worms or viruses which spread on their own.

cards.title: Turing Test
cards.content: Alan Turing, the father of AI, proposed a test in 1950. A human judge chats with a computer and a human (via text). If the judge cannot tell which is which, the computer has passed the Turing Test. For decades, this was the gold standard of AI. Today, LLMs like ChatGPT pass it easily. We are now in a post-Turing world where 'sounding human' is easy. The new challenge isn't intelligence; it's truth. A machine can lie convincingly. We need new tests for consciousness and accuracy, not just imitation.
cards.keyTakeaway: A test to see if a computer can fool a human into thinking it's human.

quiz.question: A computer passes the Turing Test if:
choices: A: It solves a math problem instantly
B: A human cannot distinguish it from another human
quiz.explanation: The test measures a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

cards.title: Deepfakes
cards.content: You see a video of the President saying something crazy. It looks real. It sounds real. It's fake. Deepfakes use 'Generative Adversarial Networks' (GANs). Imagine two AIs: The Forger and The Detective. The Forger creates a fake image. The Detective spots the flaws. The Forger learns and tries again. They do this millions of times until the Forger creates a fake so perfect the Detective can't spot it. This technology is growing faster than our ability to detect it. In the future, 'seeing is believing' will no longer be true.
cards.keyTakeaway: AI-generated fake videos created by two AIs competing against each other.

quiz.question: How do Deepfakes improve so fast?
choices: B: Two AIs compete against each other to perfect the fake
quiz.explanation: GANs involve a generator and a discriminator network competing to create the most realistic output.

cards.title: The Singularity
cards.content: This is the ultimate sci-fi concept. The Singularity is a hypothetical point in the future when technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible. It happens when we create an AI that is smarter than humans. That AI then builds a *better* AI, which builds an even *better* one. Intelligence explodes. We can't predict what happens after that because we can't understand a mind smarter than ours—just like a dog can't understand the internet. Will it be utopia? Or Terminator? We don't know, but many think we are getting close.
cards.keyTakeaway: The moment AI becomes smarter than humans and improves itself uncontrollably.

quiz.question: What happens after the Singularity?
choices: B: It is impossible to predict (technological explosion)
quiz.explanation: It refers to an event horizon beyond which human prediction fails due to the emergence of superintelligence.
